title: 108_hr4793
content: The Act is titled the "Justice and Understanding By International Loan Elimination and Equity Act of 2004" or the "JUBILEE Act of 2004". The Congress finds that many poor countries are burdened by international debts, some of which were incurred by dictatorships and not used for the benefit of the population. International Jubilee coalitions advocate for full debt cancellation for these impoverished countries. The IMF has imposed harsh conditions on poor countries for past loans and debt relief programs. Justice demands full debt cancellation for these countries. SEC. 1626 of the International Financial Institutions Act calls for the cancellation of debt owed by eligible poor countries. SEC. 1626 of the International Financial Institutions Act calls for multilateral debt cancellation in eligible poor countries through international financial institutions like the Paris Club, IMF, and World Bank. The institutions are required to cancel debts owed by these countries and finance the cancellation from their operations. The International Financial Institutions Act calls for multilateral debt cancellation in eligible poor countries through institutions like the Paris Club, IMF, and World Bank. Debt cancellation should not exceed 1 month from the application date. Countries are encouraged to allocate 20% of their budget for basic services like healthcare, education, and clean water. Input from civil society is important. A framework for creditor transparency is established to monitor creditor activity. The Secretary of the Treasury will work with international financial institutions to promote transparency in their activities, including project design, monitoring, and decision-making. Efforts will be made to allow input from affected communities. The Secretary of the Treasury will promote transparency in international financial institutions by providing information on proposed projects, oral briefings, and dialogue with community organizations. The remarks of the United States Executive Director at meetings of international financial institutions will be available on the Treasury Department website. The IMF, World Bank, and other international financial institutions may consider debt cancellation or reduction, with sensitive information redacted by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Comptroller General will report on the operations and accounts within a year. The IMF, World Bank, and other international financial institutions may consider debt cancellation for eligible poor countries. The President must submit an annual report to relevant committees on the progress made in achieving this goal. The President must submit an annual report listing countries that received debt cancellation, those denied, and those under consideration. The Secretary of the Treasury must ensure creditors contribute to debt reduction without affecting poverty alleviation programs. Eligible poor countries include Angola, Bangladesh, Benin, Bolivia, and others. Countries eligible for debt cancellation include Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cambodia, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Kenya, Lao PDR, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Peru, Philippines, Republic of Congo, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Vietnam, Yemen, and Zambia, unless they have excessive military expenditures or support terrorism. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 outlines conditions for debt cancellation eligibility, including failure to cooperate on narcotics control, gross human rights violations, and lack of free and fair elections in Haiti. SEC. 1627 prohibits structural adjustment programs under the International Financial Institutions Act. The Secretary of the Treasury is tasked with ensuring debt cancellation for eligible poor countries is not tied to policies that worsen poverty or harm the environment, such as implementing user fees on education or healthcare. The curr_chunk discusses the potential negative impacts of increased cost recovery from poor people to finance public services like education and healthcare. It highlights how this could raise costs for consumers with incomes below $2 per day for access to clean drinking water, through reduced subsidies, privatization, and undermining workers' rights. The curr_chunk discusses the President's obligation to submit an annual report to Congress on activities related to worker rights under the Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Programs Appropriations Act.
